title: Ângelo Martins
text:
Ângelo Gaspar Martins (19 April 1930 – 11 October 2020), simply known as Ângelo, was a Portuguese <a href="Association%20football">footballer</a> who played as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29">defender</a> for <a href="S.L.%20Benfica">Benfica</a> and the <a href="Portugal%20national%20football%20team">Portugal national team</a>.
Club career.
Born in <a href="Porto">Porto</a> on 19 April 1930, Ângelo turned down an opportunity to play <a href="association%20football">football</a> for <a href="FC%20Porto">FC Porto</a> because he was a supporter of rivals <a href="S.L.%20Benfica">Benfica</a>, from <a href="Lisbon">Lisbon</a>, and hometown club <a href="S.C.%20Salgueiros">Salgueiros</a>.
In 1945, aged 15, Ângelo started his career playing as a <a href="left%20defender">left defender</a> for <a href="Acad%C3%A9mico%20F.C.">Académico do Porto</a>, where he spent three years until he was scammed by an FC Porto staff member, who gave him a false document and made him sign for the club while he still was an Académico do Porto player. As a result, the <a href="Portuguese%20Football%20Federation">Portuguese Football Federation</a> (FPF) banned Ângelo from football, although the punishment would only last for a few months.
Three years later, when Ângelo was a worker at his father's shoe store and was serving in the military in <a href="Santar%C3%A9m%2C%20Portugal">Santarém</a> at age 20, a Benfica <a href="Scout%20%28sport%29">scout</a> watched him play and brought him to Lisbon in 1951 to represent Benfica's reserves, with the FPF backing down on his ban. During his 13 seasons with "The Eagles"' main team, from 1952 to 1965, he made 285 appearances and scored 4 goals, winning 7 <a href="Primeira%20Liga">Primeira Liga</a> titles, 5 <a href="Ta%C3%A7a%20de%20Portugal">Taça de Portugal</a>, 1 <a href="Ta%C3%A7a%20de%20Honra">Taça de Honra</a>, and 2 consecutive <a href="European%20Cup">European Cup</a>s (in <a href="1960%20European%20Cup%20Final">1961</a> and <a href="1962%20European%20Cup%20Final">1962</a>). He retired as a player at age 35.
International career.
Ângelo played for <a href="Portugal%20national%20football%20team">Portugal</a> on 20 occasions. He made his debut in 1953 against <a href="Austria%20national%20football%20team">Austria</a> at the <a href="Prater%20Stadium">Prater Stadium</a> and played his final match for the country in 1962 against <a href="Bulgaria%20national%20football%20team">Bulgaria</a> at the <a href="Est%C3%A1dio%20do%20Restelo">Estádio do Restelo</a>.
Death.
Ângelo died of natural causes at 90 years old, on 11 October 2020, in the company of his family.
Honours.
Player.

Manager.
